I don't think that you're seeing unburned powder leaving the barrel before the projectile. I think that Shockwave your seeing is the compressed air getting shoved out of the suppressor. The limited diameter and volume of the barrel is causing it to compress as the uncompressable bullet pushes against it.

For that to be "unburned powder" the barrel would have to be fouled from a previously fired cartridge, or the propulsion gasses would have to be powerful enough to push powder past the bullet in the barrel. This is very unlikely as the projectile has already "opterated" (expanded into the rifling to create a gas seal allowing the propulsion gasses to push it down the barrel.

This front wave is commonly referred to as "first round pop", after you fire the first bullet the system is heated, making the atmosphere inside the system less dense, and less resistant to the push from the second projectile.

I'm someone who firmly sits more towards the control side of the gun control argument, now I'm not here to discuss my beliefs or trying to invoke any sort of discussion that will inevitably get heated, I'm just using that as a preface when I say that I'm also fascinated by the sciences involved with firearms or ballistic weapons and how they work, I also love watching taofledermaus where they'll take really wacky engineered shapes and shoot them through a shotgun to see how they behave in action compared to typical shot. At the end of the day a gun by its very principle is a great way to explore the science behind high velocity objects in motion, because at its core a gun is a compact system for launching a projectile at a high velocity in a controlled manner, so long as you have something to catch the bullet at the other end.

Even with the beliefs I have, I do find it a tad sad that there are people that are unable to separate a simple appreciation for and a desire to learn about the sciences involved and a straight up glorification of weaponry

Two quick observations about gas flow exiting the muzzle.

Multiple trained ballisticians with whom I have spoken indicate that the gases “instantaneously” accelerate to approximately 1.5 times the muzzle velocity of the bullet. That does several things. One is that it creates a brief reverse flow of gasses around the bullet which easily accounts for your observation that local supersonic flow around a subsonic bullet did not appear until it had traveled a short distance from the muzzle. Another is that the reverse flow may upset the bullet causing it to either become unstable or delay it “going to sleep” as is sometimes observed with VLD bullets. Obviously, supersonic has flow is going to generate more noticeable noise than subsonic gas flow. There are a number of factors here. Gas pressure at bullet exit from the muzzle and gas volume come readily to mind.

The second is gas flow which precedes bullet exit from the muzzle. That is generally regarded as flow around the bullet as it is engraved by the rifling or less than perfect sealing with the rifling. It is more or less taken as a given because it is of a small magnitude and does not appear to affect accuracy.

If you take the F=ma equation into account (with just basic measurements), the force (the explosion of propellant) is the same acting on all particles. So the only real variable is the mass of the particles involved affecting the acceleration. The mass of a bit of powder is obviously going to be much smaller than the slug. So it makes sense that the unspent powder would be thrust out with the explosion wave before the heavier slug. That also explains how you can get powder residue on your hands after firing a weapon.

The speed of sound is c = sqrt(kRT), so c increases as T increases.  Those normal shock waves may not appear immediately because the bullet is at first traveling in higher temperature gas that has been ejected from the gun, so in that higher temperature zone there is no supersonic flow.  Then as the bullet gets further from the muzzle the air around it is ambient room temperature, where the speed of sound is slower and the shock waves appear.

The unburned propellant particles you're seeing are almost certainly not from the cartridge being fired, but as you suggested, from a previous shot.

As your buddy indicated, an optimal propellant charge will fully combust over the length of the barrel. Even in cases where the theoretical model indicates 100% burn, the reality is that there's usually a little bit of residue that didn't conform to the model, leaving some behind in the barrel or suppressor baffles. Subsonic cartridges are particularly prone to this behavior because nitrocellulose powder burn rates are, in part, a function of the pressure of the burn chamber, and because subsonic cartridges have a hard cap on their velocity, so they struggle to reach sufficient pressure and barrel time to get complete combustion under any circumstance.

300 Blackout uses a .308" diameter projectile and standard American 30 caliber bore. The diameter of across the grooves will be .308" and the diameter across the lands will be .304", or very near to it. Once the projectile has engaged the rifling, there should be little to no blow-by of gasses, let alone powder grains. Common propellants for the 300 Blackout cartridge will have small, spherical granules that average .019" in diameter.

Given that it is a long, heavy-for-caliber projectile, I also doubt that it is a case of the trailing edge of the bearing surface clearing the case mouth before the leading edge of the bearing surface is fully engaged with the rifled bore. This, to me, eliminates the possibility of gas blow-by between the projectile and the unrifled free bore portion of the chamber. This difference will be approximately .001" in diameter, so even with a bullet having a shorter bearing surface than the free bore, there isn't sufficient clearance for the propellant granules.

So the granules are most certainly not from the cartridge being fired, but where is their propulsion coming from? Fluid mechanics is not my forte. However, my suspicion is that the ambient air molecules from the chamber to the muzzle are being compressed, by the accelerating projectile, faster than the the air is able to flow out of the muzzle at ambient temperature and pressure. At some point, the pressure is becomes high enough to flow out of the muzzle above Mach and carry the residual powder granules out at transsonic or even hypersonic velocity.

Great video! I was thinking the part where you noticed that the normal shockwaves aren't forming on the subsonic bullet until it is a few inches out of the muzzle. It seems to me it has to do with the temperature of the gas coming out of the firearm. The sound speed in a fluid increases with the square root of its temperature. As the bullet moves from the hot exhaust gas to the cooler ambient air, the sound speed is dropping, so it doesn't actually enter a transonic flow regime until it reaches this point. It could also be affected by differences in some of the other properties of the gas that change as it moves into the room temperature air. Not 100% sure, but seems reasonable to me.

I'll be very interested to know if you find more info about why the transonic shockwaves don't form on the subsonic bullet until some time after it leaves the muzzle.

In regards to powder exiting the muzzle before the bullet:
It is most likely powder from the current round and not fouling from prior shoots. In firearms that are rifled there is a part of the barrel just in front of the camber (the place where the round is held) that is not rifled. This part of the barrel is called free-bore. On a .300 blackout barrel (the caliber of the rifle shown) the free-bore is about 0.1740 inch long by 0.309 wide. That gives 0.0045 inch on either side of the bullet for grains of powder to get pushed past the bullet and down the barrel. Because the powder has less mass then the bullet it will be accelerated faster then the bullet would be even though they both are being pushed by the same force, the powder burning from the primer (back of the casing) up to the neck of the casing (the front). I know this is long winded but I hope it answers the question of why powder got out in front of the bullet.

How could unburnt powder pass the bullet in the barrel if it starts the process behind the bullet? If I'm correct, once the ignition is made, the bullet is pushed forward just slightly before it engages the barrel fully creating a pressure seal. Once the bullet has fully engaged the barrel there is no way for the powder to escape until the bullet has completed its travel down the barrel. When I saw the specks flying out before the bullet, I immediately was thinking it was simply carbon buildup coming loose and being forced out the front of the barrel by the pressure wave created in front of the bullet like a piston in an air pump forcing air out the front. This is very likely to be the case since suppressors build up carbon quickly but also expel that build up with the massive pressure being put through them.

If there are no normal shocks at 4:46 I think it's because the exhaust gases make the air flow follow the bullet at relatively the same speed. So the air flow relative to the bullet is indeed not transonic

I think one things that wasn't touched on in the video is that during the side by side comparison at 2:42 , the suppressed bullet comes out of the barrel supersonic, whereas the unsuppressed bullet in transonic, showing a positive effect that a suppressor can have by increasing muzzle velocity (if that is desired). It could also be that the shockwave is obstructed in the blast on the right, or infact that the shockwave does not yet exisit as the muzzle blast has made the environment transonic momentarily.

Also the reason that the transonic projectile takes longer before the shockwaves appear (second slow mo clip) would be due to the fact the that muzzle blast/fluid around the projectile is likely moving quick enough to make the environment subsonic, until the blast flow slows down 6 inches from the muzzle, during which time the projectiles velocity has changed very little, and it becomes transonic again.

Most of us that subscribe love the science and in a world where we now have to ask forgiveness before upsetting someone is upsetting to me. Leave the apologizing to the practitioners. Scientist observe and collect data. What that data is used for is not a scientists job, that goes to any practitioner such as engineers, doctors or politicians. An example of this is when all of us are born and are young, we observe the world around us. Young humans collect data by testing and stressing ideas such as " What if I push this spoon off of my tabletop, what will momma do?" Hi Destin. I reload bullets and the unburnt powder thing is fascinating. There is a little space in the barrel of a rifle in front of the brass case neck where the projectile seats that doesn't have any riflings. Careful reloaders want to make this space as small as possible without actually touching the riflings so that there will be less "jump" as we call it, for more accuracy. Factories making bullets only care that the projectile isn't too long, so there is usually plenty of space in there with a factory load. Another thing that happens is that when a bullet is fired, the brass case expands slightly to match almost exactly the interior of the firing chamber. What is interesting to me is that (I guess) powder directly behind the bullet, being lighter than the bullet and feeling the effects of the building pressure sooner, must be slipping around the bullet while it's in that little space in front of the brass case neck. Assuming it's not burnt powder from the previous shot. Burnt powder would probably be to light and too small to be detected with your Schlieren device.

I think the faster "unburned propellant" is easy to explain away. The barrel is rifled. I think what you saw leave the barrel was copper jacket from the rifling. So as the bullet has a ton of force behind it, that same force is being applied to the copper in the rifling adjacent to the bullet. The bullet has a "large" surface area for the gases to apply force. The rifle area has a tiny surface area having the same force applied to it. So like water out of a hose with your thumb over the end, the gases are pressing hard enough on the copper in the rifling that it's slinging them out faster than the bullet.

This is further demonstrated by the fact that we know gases leave the barrel first. The bullet is slightly smaller than the inner barrel diameter. The only way those gases are getting out first is through the rifling. It would make sense that the gases would push copper and other unburned powder along with it. Likely even the very copper off the bullet being fired.

Destin,
I hope this doesn't come off as a nit-pick, but those cones you're observing on airplanes aren't actually formed by shockwaves. They indicate that there is a rapid pressure drop, in some cases due to supersonic flow in front of them, and the cone boundary is actually the start of the expansion fan (in the transonic case), which is essentially the opposite of a shockwave (nerd term is Prandtl-Meyer expansion fan). You can get those same condensation clouds under a myriad of conditions, some with flow that is well below the transonic region. (Take a look at pictures of fighters at high AoA 'vaping', a phenomenon that's happening at very low Mach numbers)

As a related note that I hope piques your curiosity, you might try observing a muzzle brake with your schlerien setup. Some brakes have straight through cuts, and I'd love to see what the flow patterns look like.

Hm so I have two theories about the normal shock waves not appearing until later. 1) at first, the gas around the bullet is traveling at a similar speed to the bullet itself, so there is not as much gas being pushed around by the tip of the bullet; the bullet and surrounding air are kinda moving as one. But then as the pressure drops and the air slows down, the bullet starts to actually push the air out of the way, accelerating it and generating the shocks. 2) The gas is initially very hot, which raises the local speed of sound such that no part of it reaches supersonic flow. As the gases cool, the local speed of sound drops until eventually areas of the flow are now supersonic.

Hey Destin! These videos are great and extraordinarily fascinating! I've worked with Kyle of The Social Regressive youtube channel. He first conducted tests with subsonic, suppressed rounds at different distances and discovered the Hollywood "pew" sound. That was a moment to celebrate because we all thought that sound was fake when in fact you just don't hear it at close distance, but it is real! Soon after that test you posted "Shockwave Shadows in Ultra Slow Motion (Bullet Schlieren)." Kyle and I had a long chat about your video and our own tests. I know you couldn't hear it in your video, but thanks to your video we are pretty sure we know WHY the bullets make the "pew" sound when they do! These tests are consistent, repeatable, and to a degree predictable. We have since conducted more tests at extreme long ranges with a camera and microphone next to a one mile target. The supersonic projectile has gone through the transonic barrier and is subsonic when it hits the target. There is still a loud "crack" from when the bullet was supersonic. It's a SUPER interesting observation! We've been able to use the sound that we recorded to recalculate some of our ballistic data and make corrections that explain/verify why our dope adjustments were different from what was initially expected using the manufacturers ballistic data. There is certainly more to test and more to learn and understand. Kyle and I would really love to talk with you, compare notes, and see what more we can learn together.

Unburnt propellant exiting before the bullet makes perfect sense to me. I am not a gunner, or a fluid dynamics scientist, but in my mind, I explain it as follows:

Unburnt propellant is likely due to the propellant's burn rate to be slower (or lower? How do I compare that?) than the kinetic energy produced by the gas expansion caused by the burning propellant in this confined chamber. It is probably necessarily that way for the propellant to be able to accelerate the bullet to the desired speed: The energy it takes to accelerate the bullet and to press it into the riflings to target speed must be exceeded by the energy produced by the burning propellant. But not too much, otherwise the chamber explodes! So timing is of an essence, and dragging out the production of that propellant energy over time helps with preventing to construct overly reinforced explosion chambers. (I am not considering the additional energy required to eject the empty shell and chamber the next round.)

This I guess comes at a cost, in that there will be unburnt propellant simply because of laws of physics: The burn rate of the propellant, as in the speed and time with which it rips through the entire volume from the back where the pin hits the shell to ignite all the way to the front where the actual bullet sits, is likely less than the time required to accelerate some propellant to a speed that exceeds the burn progression - and accelerating little specs of propellant takes much less energy and time to accelerate the bullet itself, which has much more mass. Therefore I think there is a "window of opportunity" for propellant to slip past the bullet into the rifle bore before the bullet is pressed into the riflings, closing off the explosion chamber to maximise on the energy to propel the bullet forward.

The result would be the little propellant specks plus some explosion gases exiting the barrel before the actual projectile as seen in your video.

I would love to see footage of what is going on in the explosion chamber to see whether my ramblings have any resemblance with reality :-) Dustin, there is your next video topic. :-D

Since I’m here, was interested if you could go into more depth some time about the interactions between bullets and solids. Some observations; in the bullet vs prince Rupert drop videos, there’s a couple times where the PRD fails at the point where the bullet impacts, setting off the glass failure front. However, due to the massive frame rates you were filming you can see in a couple shots that a second failure occurs at the tail end and meets the initial fracture somewhere in the middle. This was interesting to me as I had originally thought that the fracture would travel at the speed of sound in glass, and that it would therefore be impossible for the tail end to ‘know’ the PRD had been hit before the fracture front reaches it. Since this isn’t the case, it must be that on impact the bullet sets off a longitudinal wave which travels faster than the failure wave? Second observation, you attribute the light seen on impact with triboluminescence, which I thought makes sense, until I saw a different shot of a PRD which does not break on impact with the bullet, still exhibit light as the bullet breaks around it. The bullet can’t exhibit triboluminescence as its not crystalline, so I think the light must be at least partially attributable to adiabatic compression of tiny trapped gas spaces between bullet and glass. 4:36 I guess it is because of the decreasing temperature: right before the bullet exits the suppressor the gas is hot whereas it gets colder as the bullet travels away from the gun. Since the speed of sound is proportional to the square root of the temperature, at a fixed bullet velocity, Mach number is increasing because the speed of sound is decreasing. It could be also due to the relative velocities: we can see unburnt powder traveling supersonic, meaning that there could be a a supersonic flow right at the end of the suppressor. So, speaking in terms of relative velocities, a subsonic bullet moving in a supersonic flow is actually moving backward with respect to the surrounding air but, as soon as the bullet reaches the outside environment, its relative velocity increases until its Mach number becomes critical, causing normal shockwaves. The gunpowder can leave the barrel before the bullet because the rifling allows gaps between the bullet and the barrel wall.

The outer diameter of the rifling (the deep parts) cannot be the diameter of the bullet or you'll get a jam because in order for the rifling to engage the bullet, it has to "bite" into the bullet which displaces material, and if you don't allow for that expansion, you get a jam.

Therefore there's a tiny gap between the part of the bullet that's untouched by the rifling and the deepest grooves of the rifling, which allows unburned gunpowder to exit the barrel before the bullet, along with enough gas to "poot" (your words not mine) what appears to be a double vortex ring.

There's also a short distance in the chamber that the bullet has to traverse after leaving the cartridge and before engaging the rifling.

Possible reason for the delayed shock waves around the subsonic bullet: I think the air just in front of the muzzle is moving in the direction of travel from the particles exiting the muzzle before the bullet. This relative motion of air to the left (away from the muzzle) makes the air speed from the bullets perspective less than if it went through stationary air. In other words the air passing over the bullet when it exits the muzzle is less than that when the bullet is in stationary air some distance away from the barrel.

When shooting fireworks from a mortar, say a perfectly round 3inch ballshell, the mortar must have an inner diameter such that there is an airgap of about a millimeter(!) between the shell and mortar-wall all around. I doubt the particles are from the cartridge being fired.  For a round to be repeatably accurate the ogive of the bullet should be past the throat of the chamber and seated into the lands before the bullet clears the case neck.  Very short pistol bullets might not be fully seated in the lands and groves of the rifling before they exit the case mouth but longer rifle bullets most certainly will be.  The super-sonic particles must be from the previously fired round. That being said, thank you for the great look at the first moments of exterior ballistics. THANK YOU, DESTIN! This last pair of videos are among my favorite you've ever done: this is groundbreaking footage depicting physical phenomena I never imagined I would directly observe like this. Please continue the firearms videos. As you suggested, they provide tremendous practical examples of all kinds of interesting things like mechanical engineering, physics, fluid dynamics, ballistics (internal, external/flight, terminal, etc.), and much more. I am so excited to be able to see the noise generated by rifles and bullets in motion, and how suppressors modify them. I may watch this footage over a hundred times. I want to learn and this is a tremendous resource that I'm sure many students, informal and formal, will be referencing, as will professionals.

The fact that we can visualize the vibrations and movement of gasses and projectiles (including unburned powder) in such high resolution and slow motion just fills me with awe not only at what humanity has accomplished and the understanding it has gained but at what it will understand and accomplish as experiments and observations like this build and deepen our knowledge. Now that we have the ability to actually view and measure the report of a firearm not just in decibels but as a visualization of the mechanics of sound, I can only imagine that this sort of thing will be very useful to understanding the fluid dynamics and how to control them for desired effects like impulse noise reduction. Which could have the very practical effect of preventing a tremendous amount of hearing loss! Permanent hearing damage is one of the most common military injuries and is also a very common occurrence in civilian life.

That even subsonic bullets can produce supersonic effects is a revelation to me. It's one thing to read a few sentences describing what happens, and another to observe it with your own eyes. I have tremendous appreciation for your work to create visual demonstrations that actually show us science heretofore that we could only read and imagine with our own eyes. It's clearly a lot more sophisticated than we could imagine, which raises further questions, which leads to more knowledge and better understanding of the universe. Thank you so very much from the bottom of my heart. God bless you and your family.
